briefdescription.para: Interface between the two involved patches.

memberdef.argsstring: (IdxRange1DPerp_1 const &idx_range_1d_1, IdxRange1DPerp_2 const &idx_range_1d_2, ddc::BoundCond const &Bound1=ddc::BoundCond::HERMITE, ddc::BoundCond const &Bound2=ddc::BoundCond::HERMITE)
memberdef.name: SingleInterfaceDerivativesCalculator

detaileddescription.para: It computes the coefficients a and b, and the weights $\omega_k$ and stores the values in the class. If you want to compute the derivatives with an exact formula, please provide the index ranges on the full domain of the patches. If you want to use an approximation (e.g. use only 5 cells), please provide the index ranges on a reduced number of cells (e.g. 5 cells).
If the interpolation points are uniform, it computes the coefficients with an explicit formula. Otherwise, it uses the recursive formula (see README.md).

parameterdescription.para: 1D index range perpendicular to the Interface, on the patch 1.
1D index range perpendicular to the Interface, on the patch 2.

The boundary condition type on the opposite edge of the interface on the patch 1. By default, the value is set to ddc::BoundCond::HERMITE. If ddc::BoundCond::GREVILLE is given, a treatment will be applied to consider the additional interpolation point. Giving ddc::BoundCond::PERIODIC does not make sense.

The boundary condition type on the opposite edge of the interface on the patch 2. By default, the value is set to ddc::BoundCond::HERMITE. If ddc::BoundCond::GREVILLE is given, a treatment will be applied to consider the additional interpolation point. Giving ddc::BoundCond::PERIODIC does not make sense.

memberdef.argsstring: (IdxRangeA const &idx_range_a, IdxRangeB const &idx_range_b, ddc::BoundCond const &Bound1=ddc::BoundCond::HERMITE, ddc::BoundCond const &Bound2=ddc::BoundCond::HERMITE)
memberdef.name: SingleInterfaceDerivativesCalculator

parameterdescription.para: Index range on the other patch.
The boundary condition type on the opposite edge of the interface on the patch 1. By default, the value is set to ddc::BoundCond::HERMITE.
The boundary condition type on the opposite edge of the interface on the patch 2. By default, the value is set to ddc::BoundCond::HERMITE.

briefdescription.para: Get the coefficient (a) in front of the derivative on the patch 1 of the given Interface.

simplesect.para: The value of the coefficient a.

briefdescription.para: Get the coefficient (b) in front of the derivative on the patch 2 of the given Interface.

simplesect.para: The value of the coefficient b.

briefdescription.para: Get the coefficient (a) or (b) in front of the derivative on the given patch of the given Interface.

simplesect.para: The value of the coefficient (a) or (b).

memberdef.argsstring: (DConstField< IdxRange1DPerp_1, Kokkos::HostSpace, Layout1 > const &function_1, DConstField< IdxRange1DPerp_2, Kokkos::HostSpace, Layout2 > const &function_2) const
memberdef.name: get_function_coefficients

briefdescription.para: Get the linear combination of the function values (c).

detaileddescription.para:
function_1
Function values at the interpolation points on patch 1.
function_2
Function values at the interpolation points on patch 2.
the linear combination of the function values (c).
Remark: for the approximation case, the cells were selected by the given index ranges in the instantiation. Here, function_1 and function_2 can be given on the whole domain and the operator will select the correct values. But, it could be more optimised to directly give a slice on the selected cells. E.g. get_function_coefficients(function_1[idx_interface_1][selected_cells_idx_range_1], function_2[idx_interface_2][selected_cells_idx_range_2]); and get_function_coefficients(function_1[idx_interface_1], function_2[idx_interface_2]); will return the same value.

memberdef.argsstring: (DConstField< IdxRange1DPerp_2, Kokkos::HostSpace, Layout2 > const &function_2, DConstField< IdxRange1DPerp_1, Kokkos::HostSpace, Layout1 > const &function_1) const
memberdef.name: get_function_coefficients

briefdescription.para: Get the linear combination of the function values (c). See get_function_coefficients.

parameterdescription.para: Function values at the interpolation points on patch 1.
Function values at the interpolation points on patch 2.

simplesect.para: the linear combination of the function values (c).

memberdef.argsstring: (bool const is_cell_bound_with_extra_interpol_pt, IdxRange< EdgePerpGrid > const &idx_range_perp, Extremity const extremity) const
memberdef.name: check_break_points_are_interpolation_points

briefdescription.para: Compute the coefficients a, b and the weights omega applying the recursive formula.

memberdef.argsstring: (int const n_cells, Idx< Grid1D > const interface_idx, std::array< double, 3 > &coeff_deriv_patch, std::array< double, 3 > &coeff_deriv_other_patch, std::array< host_t< DField< IdxRange1DPerp_1 > >, 3 > &weights_patch1, std::array< host_t< DField< IdxRange1DPerp_2 > >, 3 > &weights_patch2)
memberdef.name: recursion

briefdescription.para: Recursion to compute the coefficients a, b and the weights omega.

detaileddescription.para:
n_cells
Number of the cells of the patch where the recursion is made.
interface_idx
Index at the interface.
The following parameters are array with three elements corresponding to the values at the step n-1, n and n+1 in the recursion.
coeff_deriv_patch
Coefficient in front of the derivative of the patch. E.g. Patch1: coeff_deriv_patch = b | Patch2: coeff_deriv_patch = a
coeff_deriv_other_patch
Coefficient in front of the derivative of the other patch. E.g. Patch1: coeff_deriv_other_patch = a | Patch2: coeff_deriv_other_patch = b
weights_patch1
Weights in front of the function values on patch 1.
weights_patch2
Weights in front of the function values on patch 2.

memberdef.argsstring: (int const n_points, Idx< Grid1D > const interface_idx, std::array< double, 3 > &coeff_deriv_patch, std::array< double, 3 > &coeff_deriv_other_patch, std::array< host_t< DField< IdxRange1DPerp_1 > >, 3 > &weights_patch1, std::array< host_t< DField< IdxRange1DPerp_2 > >, 3 > &weights_patch2)
memberdef.name: correction_boundary

briefdescription.para: Correction of the local coefficients on the boundary for additional interpolation points in the middle of a cell.

detaileddescription.para:
n_points
Number of interpolation points on the patch where the correction is made.
interface_idx
Index at the interface.
The following parameters are array with three elements corresponding to the values at the step n-1, n and n+1 in the recursion.
coeff_deriv_patch
Coefficient in front of the derivative of the patch. E.g. Patch1: coeff_deriv_patch = b | Patch2: coeff_deriv_patch = a
coeff_deriv_other_patch
Coefficient in front of the derivative of the other patch. E.g. Patch1: coeff_deriv_other_patch = a | Patch2: coeff_deriv_other_patch = b
weights_patch1
Weights in front of the function values on patch 1.
weights_patch2
Weights in front of the function values on patch 2.

briefdescription.para: Compute the derivative of an equivalent global spline at the interface between two patches.

detaileddescription.para: For a given Interface, this operator computes the coefficients a, b and c of the following relation: $ s'(X_I) = c + a s'(X_{I+1}) + b s'(X_{I+1})$,

with
s'(X_I) the derivative at the Interface of the two local splines on the patches.
s'(X_{I+1}) the derivative at the next (or right) Interface of the local splines on patch 1.
s'(X_{I-1}) the derivative at the previous (or left) Interface of the local splines on patch 2.
a,b scalars depending on the meshes of the two patches.
c a linear combination of the function values on the two patches. The weights in the linear combination depend on the meshes of the two patches. It can be written as a sum: $ c = \sum_{k = -N2}^{N1} \omega_k f_k$, with $ \omega_k $ the weights, $ f_k $ the function values, $ N1 $ the number of cells in patch 1, and $ N2 $ the number of cells in patch 2.

Scheme of the two patches: X_{I-1} X_I X_{I+1} | | | | 1 | 2 | |_______|_______|
+
- Orientation of an equivalent global mesh :
All the formulae and more details are given in the README.md.

parameterdescription.para: The interface between two patches where we want to compute the derivatives.

simplesect.para: The applied method only works for interpolation points located on the break points. In the case where "ddc::BoundCond::GREVILLE" is specified, additional interpolation points are also placed in the first or last cell of the patch. Please be sure to initialise the discrete space of your Grid on the break points (especially in the non-uniform case).
